ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT:
The dimension of thermal conductivity is

where, M is mass, L is length, T is time and K is thermodynamic temperature

A long cylinder of 12 cm diameter is generating uniform internal heat of 2 × 107 W/m3 by nuclear material. It is cooled at its outer surface by heavy water to maintain its surface temperature at 90°C. If the thermal conductivity of the material is 40 W/mK, the temperature at a radial distance of 3 cm from the centre at steady state is
The ratio of heat conduction rate to thermal energy storage rate is interpretated as

A rod of 4 cm diameter and 25 cm length is maintained at 300°C at one end and 20°C at the other end. If these end temperatures are attained when there is heat flow rate of 80 W, then the thermal conductivity of the rod material assuming one dimensional heat conduction is

A plane wall of thickness 0.2 m and thermal conductivity 25 W/mK generates uniform internal heat at 60 kW/m3 when an electric current is passed through it. The coefficient of convective heat transfer on each side of the wall is 10 W/m2K and and surrounding temperature is 25°C. Under steady state, the maximum temperature in the wall is

Air at 30°C blows over a hot plate (thermal conductivity = 20 W/mK, thickness = 2 cm) of 1 m × 1 m surface which is maintained at 250°C. The film conductance is 30 W/m2K and heat loss through radiation from the surface of the plate is 3300 W. The temperature of the bottom surface of the plate is _______ °C

(Round off to one decimal place)

A solid copper cylinder of diameter 10 cm and length 20 cm is taken out from liquid nitrogen at –196°C and exposed to air at 25°C with convection heat transfer coefficient 20 W/m2K. The thermal conductivity of copper is 400 W/mK and that of air is 0.05 W/mK. The Biot number for air in contact with copper cylinder is _______ × 10–5. (Answer in integer)

A current carrying electrical wire of diameter 4 mm is insulated with a material. The thermal conductivity of wire material is 0.4 W/mK and that of insulation material is 0.1 W/mK. If the convective heat transfer of outer surface exposed to air is 20 W/m2K, then the critical thickness of insulation for maximum heat dissipation is _______ mm. (Correct upto 1 decimal place)
Which of the following statement(s) is/are INCORRECT regarding fins?
ENGLISH.OPT1: Increase in the ratio of cross-sectional area to the perimeter increases the effectiveness of fin.
ENGLISH.OPT2: Increase in thermal conductivity of fin material increases the effectiveness of fin.
ENGLISH.OPT3: On increasing the length of the fin, the fin effectiveness decreases.
ENGLISH.OPT4: On increasing the length of the fin, the fin efficiency increases.

ENGLISH.QUESTION_TEXT: The inside surface of an insulating layer is at 350°C and the outside surface is dissipating heat by convection into air at 20°C. The insulating layer is 50 mm thick and has a thermal conductivity of 1.5 W/mK. If the maximum allowable outside surface temperature is 80°C, the minimum value of heat transfer coefficient at the outside surface is

Convection heat transfer is carried out from water at 50°C to glass plate whose surface is exposed to water. The glass surface temperature is 34°C.

The thermal conductivity of water and glass are 0.5 W/mK and 1.2 W/mK, respectively. If the spatial gradient of temperature in the water at water-glass interface is the convective heat transfer coefficient is

Consider a hydrodynamically fully developed laminar flow through a pipe of diameter 6 mm under uniform wall temperature boundary conditions. If the thermal conductivity of fluid is 0.16 W/mK and bulk mean temperature difference between the wall and the fluid is 60°C, the rate of heat transfer per meter length between the tube wall and fluid is

Water flows through a circular pipe of 40 mm diameter at 10 m/s. The tube is maintained at uniform temperature of 60°C and water is heated from inlet temperature of 10°C to outlet temperature of 30°C. The properties of water at 20°C are

The average heat transfer coefficient from the tube surface to water is approximately

A circular pipe is insulated which carries a hot fluid. Inner and outer diameters of pipe are 200 mm and 400 mm, respectively and thickness of insulation laid on the pipe is 20 mm. The temperature of hot fluid is 300°C and that of surrounding is 30°C. The thermal conductivity of pipe material and insulation material is 300 W/mK and 0.05 W/mK, respectively. Considering the heat transfer coefficient on inside and outside as 700 W/m2K and 40 W/m2K respectively, the heat loss per meter length of pipe is _______ W/m. (Round off to the nearest integer value)

A copper rod of diameter 0.6 cm and length 50 cm protrudes from a wall maintained at a temperature of 500°C. The surrounding temperature is 27°C and convective heat transfer coefficient is 45 W/m2K. Assuming thermal conductivity of copper as 400 W/mK, the heat transfer from the fin is ________ W.

(Round off to two decimal places)

A metal sphere of diameter 2 cm is initially at 300°C. The ball is quenched in water at 20°C and heat transfer coefficient 100 W/m2K. The thermal conductivity, density and specific heat of metal is 60 W/mK, 7800 kg/m3 and 434 J/kgK, respectively. The temperature of the metal sphere after 3 min will be approximately _______ °C. (Round off to 1 decimal place)

Air at atmospheric pressure and 210°C flows over a flat plate with a velocity of 4 m/s. The plate is 20 mm wide and is maintained at a temperature of 130°C. The properties of air ρ = 0.8 kg/m3; μ = 25 × 10–6 Ns/m2; k = 0.036 W/mK and Pr = 0.7.
Which of the above statement(s) is/are correct?
ENGLISH.OPT1: The thickness of thermal boundary layer at a distance of 0.5 m from the leading edge is 9.88 mm.
ENGLISH.OPT2: The thickness of thermal boundary layer at a distance of 0.5 m from the leading edge is 10.85 mm.
ENGLISH.OPT3: The local heat transfer coefficient at a distance of 0.5 m from the leading edge is 5.37 W/m2K.
ENGLISH.OPT4: The local heat transfer coefficient at a distance of 0.5 m from the leading edge is 0.79 W/m2K.
